ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim is very smart and very good in teaching. He is the bridge between Susan and students. I definitely consider him as an important piece of the "soul" of the class.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  I think Tim is already awesome in the way he is teaching. He is definitely great in accepting feedback, which I really appreciate it. The only thing that I have in mind to improve his teaching skill is to ask him paying attention not only on the brightest students, but also to the quiet ones.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Generally, Tim helped balance Susan and was a great asset. He could benefit from not cutting students off. Someone told me they scheduled an appointment with him, and he ended up speaking for most of the time. He could work on his listening skills.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Good at leading discussion and a good compliment to Susan's teaching style.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Very engaged and committed. He was very responsive to student questions and adapted material to each individual. Tim is an incredible teaching fellow and truly co-instructed the class. I think he could improve by making the discussion part of the class more student driven or led rather than just a summary of journals.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was a very helpful teaching assistant for the course. I believe that Susan Clark and Tim complemented each other very well for the material and appreciated both of their outlooks on the subject. He always made himself available and was open to helping all of us.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was a very strong teaching assistant. He in fact held the class together and could be considered the most crucial part to the course's success.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim essentially co-taught the class with Susan, and was often able to articulate concepts even more clearly and with more explicit examples than Susan. I think the only comment I would make about Tim is that he often takes an academic perspective, which is understandable given his current role at FES - but he is at least quick to critique the academic institutions that he is a part of.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Class is very well organized, and conducted in an organized manner. The only genuinely interdisciplinary course available at FES. The learning environment is open and very cooperative and attuned to students' pace and needs. Not suited for students not prepared to engage in very self-reflective activities or to have their worldview brought into analysis.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was a fantastic facilitator for our discussions and great at clarifying concepts.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: If you consistently battle between you and your thoughts, this class will definitely give you a skill set to structure your thoughts with policy science framework. For me, this class does not only offer me a skill set, but it has opened my eyes and my mind on how the world evolves in multidimensional aspect. Throughout the semester, we talked a lot on issues that are not commonly or normally discussed in every day conversation, but we know how important they are, and we realize their existences around us, such as human dignity, common interest, values, etc. For me, this class also gave valuable opportunities through its exercises to understand my own self, and to increase my awareness on my surrounding. For me, this class was also a part of spiritual journey for myself.

Its a very different course. It will make you think about yourself and your other courses in a new light - which I found valuable. It was also frustrating. Susan is a little bit out there, Tim helped bring her back down to earth. But still, they spent a little too much time talking - the class would have benefited a lot from more open discussion.

While Susan is not always the most engaging lecturer, she really mentors students and makes course content relevant to everyone. She challenges and nurtures students in a very effective way. This means that in class, she can be a little hard to follow because her lectures are a bit tangential, but in her office hours she is very clear and insightful.
Excellent course, my favorite of this semester. It's a valuable tool for professionals interested in policy issues.

The structure of this class, particularly in the first 1-3 meetings, is a bit off-putting or at least disconcerting, which I think turns many students away - I didn't feel like I really understood the angle of the class until the third or fourth meeting. Once things started to click, though, I realized that this will probably be the most valuable class I take as a student interested in natural resource policy issues. I think Tim and Susan run a risk of turning students away by not being more basically clear about what the class is about up front - but on the other hand, if the class had more than 15 or so students in it, I believe it would be less effective, so I wouldn't necessarily encourage an approach that caused the class to be bigger.
Incredible class. Very likely the best, most worthwhile experience available at FES.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspect of this course was that you would learn on something that you did not expect you would gain from this class, and they were extremely valuable things.

self reflection was incredibly valuable. most classes there is no space for that. but we are all humans - and thats very important to remember. but we dont always and most courses dont even acknowledge or seem to understand that.
gaining a well-versed understanding of the policy sciences.

I really enjoyed almost all of the course. The journals, reading, exercises, and small discussion groups were very engaging and stimulating. The course is very holistic and covers a lot of ground. The case study aspect allowed me to put the theory into practice and I got a lot out of the process of applying the policy sciences framework. The subject of my case is now much clearer. I also enjoyed that nothing is off the table for discussion and course content--the course structure is consistent with the content.
Students could participate and lead the discussions. Susan and Tim really care about the students.

This course should be a requirement in the curriculum because it is able to integrate all aspects of environmental management and 'specializes' in integration. Although the course material can be a little overwhelming at first, it is a very good class. I would highly recommend it.

The best aspect of this course was Tim leadership and the contributions of my classmates in class and in discussion. I felt there was a lot to be learned from the subject matter, and being exposed to the policy sciences but I did not feel that it was actually the course structure or professor's efforts that lead to the success of the class. I believe my classmates interest and commitment to listen to each other and offer thoughtful feedback was what made the course worthwhile.

It provides an extremely outside-the-box perspective - one that I understand is not available in other courses at FES. Encourages the type of critical thinking and evaluation that is needed in natural resource management.
I very much appreciated the self-reflection this course required.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The weekly reading materials were way too much!

Let the students talk more. I would strongly suggest having drafts of the paper due earlier - I am working on it now...I only just started a couple days ago. This is how most students are...we have other priorities. And we are only going to learn the framework if we apply it! It would be good to talk about some of the questions I have no with the class! This is of course partly my fault.
This course could use a real world component. It would have been great to have created our policy process paper and then gone out to use it in some way with guidance by Tim and Susan.

I think it would be helpful to have a few more "assignments" where we either apply the policy sciences framework to a given prompt or to our case. With a new framework and lexicon I think it would be very helpful to apply parts of it earlier to really get practice earlier on in the course. I know that we are graduate students should be responsible for managing our workloads, but some structure for reviewing and practicing the policy sciences prior to the final project would be helpful.

The only aspect of this course that I would improve would be to have more 'hands-on' opportunities to practice the policy sciences framework in a real-time setting. I think that either having a class trip to a conference or a requirement to critique a few meetings would be a great way to practice different aspects of the framework. Additionally, I believe that the first few classes should be spent less on justifying the framework.

The presentations given by Professor Clark were not valuable. There were impossible to follow and rarely offered useful conclusions. While i believe she has a lot to offer the school as an adviser her lecture style is disjointed and unclear.

The course has a weird cadence, for lack of a better word, in large part due to the somewhat wandering nature of the discussions we would have during each meeting. I think this type of pacing and structure made for a more interesting form of self-discovery than other more structured classes, though, so I wouldn't necessarily suggest anything changes here. Just an observation.

It can be difficult to find a good balance between lecture/etc. and discussion. I would suggest continuing to fine-tune this balance. I always felt like discussion was cut short, especially at the beginning of the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The discussion portions were very good. The small groups allowed us to talk about whatever we wanted to and really helped solidify the readings and theory. I think it would be great to have groups do report-backs each week to go over some of the points they discussed with the whole class. Or to have one or two students lead a short discussion every class in addition to Tim's discussion time. A few people didn't participate as much as others. I don't think that it was because some hogged the time, but perhaps their learning styles were different. Maybe if they were required to lead a discussion or activity of their choosing there could be more widespread participation.
The discussion group was the most valuable part of the class. As stated above, the thoughts and considerations brought to the table by my classmates were what i got out of the class.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Makes me reflect on my purpose, goals, self. This is exactly what I wanted from the course...it was mostly successful in encouraging me to do that.

This course has provided a very good foundation for helping develop my course of study. It has helped me think about how I want to work later on and what skills will help me to do that. It has allowed me to think and understand what it means to be interdisciplinary.

Since I plan to go into the environmental policy field, this course was very helpful for my career. I would like to continue using the policy science framework in the future and believe that the ability to integrate is crucial for success of any initiative.
I would say that rather than this course "fitting" into my "overall program," this course has shined a new light on it and may lead me in new directions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to have a different perspective on looking at natural resources problems.
reason I said above.
I do not have a background in policy but know it it important to understand. I am really glad I took the course to gain this knowledge.
I wanted to take a smaller, discussion based course that would help me better understand decision making in relation to land and resource management.

Initially, because I wanted to learn more about "natural resource policy and management." Though the course ended up being very different from what I expected, what I got out of it was extremely valuable.

I didn't think I would take this course because "policy" always meant "laws and regulations" to me. However, after the first class I went to during shopping period, I saw that this course was much more than what I ever thought 'policy' could mean. I wanted to understand more.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Beyond my expectation.
7.5 out of 10
yes!
Yes, very much so.
Absolutely yes.
This course went above and beyond my expectations.
Yes. Actually, I would say it far exceeded my expectations.
Yes. I expected to learn about the policy sciences framework, and I did! Learning to apply the framework will be a continual process.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The small group discussion was very valuable in talking/discussing on the issues that we learned from readings/class. It also helped me to understand the material better. And, it also gave me so much laughs from our interaction.
My group wasnt very focused. I liked the idea of it a lot more than actually doing it.
The small group was one of the best parts to the class because it allowed us to work through questions and confusions.
The discussion group is a great way to understand in different and better ways the readings and class discussions.
The weekly discussion groups were a little time consuming, but I really appreciated them. I believe that discussing the concepts was a very important part of the course.

The outside-of-class discussion groups were sometimes useful and sometimes not-so-useful, but that just depended on the week and on the group's level of engagement with that particular batch of readings.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Dont think twice. Take this class!

Get ready for something different. You might love this. You might hate it. Cant have too many expectations. Be open to it. Go with your gut reaction after the first two classes. Its definitely not for everyone.
Give it a try
Everyone at FES, no mattter your concentration, should take this class. Learning the policy sciences framework can be useful to anyone dealing with natural resources management issues.

If you are feeling lost at FES and unclear about what to make of seemingly impossible problems, I encourage you to take this class. It will challenge you to think through problems in a new way--both as they relate to the greater world and to yourself within it. I recommend that you seek out Susan outside of class to help fill any gaps in your understanding. She is an incredible mentor that really cares about her students. I think some folks feel a bit nervous or don't quite understand the course in the beginning, stick with it! It will be worth. It is very hard to describe the course adequately to people who haven't taken it, but I promise it will be fulfilling if you take it and really apply yourself.
It takes longer than other courses to understand what's going on... however it's worth it. I really enjoy this class.
I would definitely recommend this course. Give it a try, and you won't be disappointed.
Make sure Tim is the TF. Allow yourself to relax and let go a little and you will enjoy the process more.

Don't be put off by its weird beginnings - it provides you with an incredibly valuable perspective on natural resource management and pushes you to think about uncomfortable but hugely important aspects of the issue.

Fellow students generally have a lot to say about this course, whether they actually took it or not or got anything out of it or not. People tend to love it or hate it. If you're interested, or think you might be, at least try it out and decide for yourself. I loved it, but don't take it on my (or anybody's) recommendation.
